ExampleText: Epistemology and the authority of science

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Activity One:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Exploring the implications of adopting a particular epistemological position is a focus for this Area of Study. In this example, students explore the authority of science. There are many scientific journals written for the lay public that deal with current research on a range of scientific pursuits. Scientific American and New Scientist are examples of such journals that can provide rich sources of study material for the classroom. In this activity, students research an article and discuss the epistemological claims made in the article. Students should be encouraged to look for key words related to epistemology, such as 'science', 'theory', 'prove', experimental findings', 'research', 'conclusions', 'truth', 'debate' and so on.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Activity Two:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Use the following sources to discuss the capacity for science to shed light on consciousness matters. The claims made in the news article 'Philosophy David Chalmers on consciousness, the hard problem and the nature of reality' can be compared with one of Chalmer's famous philosophical rivals, Daniel Dennett, through the article 'Daniel Dennett's Science of the Soul'. Finally, 'A Test for Consciousness' examines whether science can shed any light on the nature of consciousness at all.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Activity Three:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Students complete a set of written responses after reading an article from a scientific magazine, journal or article they have sourced themselves. They think initially about the epistemological status of the knowledge presented:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Can the methods of observation, experiment and/or measurement presented be trusted?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Does the problem of induction undermine the assertions made? Or is the problem of induction irrelevant? Why or why not?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Does the article provide an account of the world or reality that is objective?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Do scientists ever reach consensus? How should this affect the level of authority that we give to science?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: William James and pragmatism

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Provide students with a summary of William James and the squirrel. A written version can be found online.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Activity:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Students discuss orally or write responses to the following questions:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Are some disputes merely verbal? Is it just a matter of defining terms?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Is morality a type of knowledge?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Is there an objective way to answer whether the hunter went around the squirrel and the tree or just the tree?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Would a subjective answer to the squirrel story provide a clear understanding of what occurred?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Is James's pragmatism a satisfactory account for the nature of truth?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Investigating certainty

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Students are divided into small groups of four or five and given blank poster paper or butchers paper.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Each group writes down three examples of what they all agree they know for certain.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: The groups complete and record the following tasks on their poster:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Why are these good examples of knowledge that is certain?
ParentText: The groups complete and record the following tasks on their poster:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: List examples of knowledge that were once regarded as certain knowledge but are now known to be false. Broadly state why they were found to be false, for example due to advances in science.
ParentText: The groups complete and record the following tasks on their poster:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Revisit answers to Question 2 above and discuss whether the agreed-on examples are really certain. As they discuss, students attempt to develop a set of criteria for something to count as a certainty.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Students share and test their responses with the class while a definition for certainty is developed. The different groups could rotate around the room to read each others' responses or they can present them to the class.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Extension:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Students discuss the challenge of scepticism and consider the arguments for and against sceptical conclusions as to knowledge claims. This is an ideal opportunity to introduce the philosopher David Hume (1711-1776). A good overview of his philosophy, with a sub-section on scepticism, can be found on the Internet Encyclopaedia of Philosophy's entry for 'David Hume'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Investigating certainty

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: This concept game can be used to investigate the difference between belief and knowledge.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: First, a set of cards should be prepared which show a range of claims such as: 'Humans have walked on the moon'; '1 + 1 = 2'; 'The school day finishes at 3:30 pm'; 'Spiders have eight legs'; 'A squared + B squared = C squared'; 'Nothing can travel faster than the speed of light' and so on. Students are given a set of cards and order them on a continuum from 'belief' at one end and 'knowledge' at the other.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Students then discuss their responses, developing a view on what must be satisfied for something to count as knowledge.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Extension:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ExampleText: Teachers may like to prepare another deck of cards that has the words 'a priori' and 'a posteriori' written on them. A third deck could have the words 'synthetic' and 'analytic' written on them. Students can then classify each knowledge statement according to whether it could be a priori or a posteriori knowledge, and then classify the truth of each claim as either synthetic or analytic. Teachers would need to teach the definitions of each of these words as used by Kant.

Subject: Philosophy
ExampleText: Unit 2

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Outcome 1:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Analyse problems in ethics and moral philosophy and related contemporary debates, evaluate viewpoints and arguments in response to these problems, and explain the interplay between ethical and moral problems and contemporary ethical and moral debates.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: As a class, discuss a series of common statements such as 'It is wrong to speed in your car' or 'It is good to give to charity' or 'You should never wear white after Labour Day'. Discuss which of these represents a personal choice and which a moral norm, and justify these determinations.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Individually, in pairs, or as a class, construct a glossary with definitions for key terms and concepts associated with ethics and morality. For example: good, bad, evil, charity, justice, ethics and so on, and gradually refine these during the unit.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: In small groups, make lists of sources of moral principles such as religion and parents. Consider which sources you have derived your principles from. Why are some sources having an impact on your values while others are not? What does this tell us about the nature of moral principles?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Consider a variety of moral principles and discuss, as a class, the degree to which each contains subjectivity. Discuss sources of objectivity and analyse the degree to which these sources could shed light on or inform moral principles.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Read an extract from David Hume's A Treatise of Human Nature on 'Hume's Fork' and discuss the difficulty presented in making statements about what should ideally be the case as opposed to what is in reality the case. Then try to justify moral statements by only using facts from the world. Finally, challenge these justifications to illustrate the leap in thinking required to derive an 'ought' from an 'is'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Use a thinking tool such as a Venn Diagram to describe the differences between 'is' and 'ought'. Is the distinction valid? Make explicit the arguments used to make these distinctions by considering, for example, David Hume or G.E. Moore.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research a religion and present its moral beliefs to the class. Discuss how the moral beliefs relate to other beliefs held within the faith.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Examine examples of animal behaviours that appear moral or immoral and consider the moral challenges these behaviours pose for the question of whether animals engage in moral behaviour or only appear to do so from a human perspective.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Consider ethical theories such as Naturalism and Relativism and discuss the effectiveness and criticisms of these theories on sources of moral principles. Apply these theories to your own moral principles to determine if they lead to absurd results.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Engage in a deep dive into the history of a nation and consider its choices over time to discuss the prospect of moral progress.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: In small groups, imagine what a society that has become 'perfectly moral' might look like and discuss whether such a society is sensible or impossible as a process for examining moral progress. Consider also creating a short piece of creative writing outlining what this society might be like.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Write an essay exploring whether moral progress is possible and what this means for the nature of ethical judgements and morality itself.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research the theory of nihilism and common proponents such as Friedrich Nietzsche. Write a short imaginative paragraph describing a person or society that subscribed to such a principle. Reflect on this piece to consider whether nihilism is a worthwhile theory.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: On moral psychology

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research and discuss any overlaps that might exist between moral psychology and moral philosophy, and what is distinctive.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Read an extract from Plato's Republic ('The Ring of Gyges') and discuss the morality of using the ring, including what a good person might do with the ring as opposed to what a bad one might do. Discuss and challenge these presumptions about good and bad people. Alternatively, watch the film Lord of the Rings and consider the one ring's powers and the behaviours this might tempt people to engage in.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Generate bystander scenarios and discuss the extent to which we are obliged to react in such scenarios. Research the bystander effect and re-examine the likelihood that we would be sufficiently motivated to act when others do not. Use this as the basis for a reflection on the difficulties of doing the right thing.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Make a class list of reasons to 'do the right thing'. Critically analyse each reason and try to rank them from 'most moral' to 'least moral'. Use these discussions as the basis for a piece of writing on what motivates you to try to be good.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Write a short-answer response to an issue associated with 'akrasia' or weakness of will raised by a philosopher such as Aristotle or Plato. Link it to a contemporary debate or issue and demonstrate how Aristotle or Plato's philosophy can assist us to understand the moral dimensions of the situation.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Write a dialogue comparing the views of an altruist and an egoist on ethical decision-making. Then reflect on the role that altruism or egoism may play in morality, if any. Suggested resources include: A podcast of 'Melvyn Bragg on Altruism', 'What is Egoism?' or 'Ayn Rand on objectivism'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Consider notable examples of altruism. Write a written reflection on 'Does morality involve altruism?' For comparison, consider egoism as an explanation of moral psychology.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research and identify whether animals exhibit moral behaviour. List examples of common moral behaviours that exist between humans and other animals, such as food sharing, care of offspring and warning of danger. Consider whether the study of animals can shed light on human ethical action and moral motivation. A stimulus for this could be a visit to a zoo or wildlife sanctuary for observation and to interview zookeepers.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Look at a series of images such as a chat bot, car, a Venus fly trap, a dog, and a crowd of people. Answer the questions: Are they all capable of being moral or immoral? Does it matter?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Read an extract from the work of a virtue theorist such as Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics and discuss the extent to which our moral actions ought to be motivated by their impact on our character.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Develop examples that consider people behaving appropriately for different reasons (such as out of habit or due to fear of punishment) to determine the moral value of their actions under those circumstances.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Read a short extract challenging Hedonism, such as that found in Plato's Gorgias, and discuss the merits and problems associated with pleasure-seeking as a motivator for moral behaviour.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Engage in a class debate on the merits of political intervention in other societies' problems. Contrast this with the obligation to focus instead on improving oneself as the basis of a discussion on the importance of character and consequence in moral decision-making.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research historical cases of charitable behaviour and philanthropy, such as Bill Gates's works, and analyse whether these actions are partly self-interested and if that makes a moral difference.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research an egregious historical event such as genocide or war or forced famine, and try to explain the motivations and moral characters that might lead to such behaviours.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Consider an ethical dilemma or ethical situation, such as giving to charity. Construct arguments for and against actions in response to this dilemma or situation. Or explore the moral motivations underpinning a moral action. The views of primary text philosophers could be used as contrast.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: On right and wrong

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Undertake a research task and present a summary of the ethical beliefs and precepts of a philosopher or school of thought such as virtue ethics (Aristotle), deontology (Kant) or consequentialism (Mill).

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Consider, as a class, a proposition related to one of the broad philosophical positions, such as: 'What really matters is not what people do but rather what their intentions are.' Respond in an essay, classroom presentation or online video.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Examine the role of pleasure in moral thinking. Pleasure or the role of pleasure in a moral life can be explored in either a dialogue or through a research task. For example, consider Bentham's hedonistic utilitarianism compared with the writings of Epicurus.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Draw a concept map that compares the various strands of utilitarianism, using entries such as positive, negative, preference, act, rule, ideal and hedonistic. Draw links between the theories to explain how each variation seeks to address the issues of others. Draw a comic exploring how a deontologist and a utilitarian might solve an ethical issue. The comic series 'Action Philosophers' could be used as stimulus.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Read an extract from John Stuart Mill's 'Utilitarianism' or Immanuel Kant's 'Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals' to discuss the relative merits of consequentialist and deontological thinking.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Make a list of actions that you consider are 'always wrong'. Try to justify this thinking. Discuss if it is ever possible to make such a claim objectively or if some form of relativism is needed to justify the original claim.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research a religious tradition and examine its central moral principles. Categorise these in so far as they conform to virtue, deontological, or consequentialist principles, and evaluate their effectiveness as moral norms.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research a practical ethical problem such as animal rights, euthanasia or affirmative action. Apply normative principles to these problems and consider key philosophers' arguments in trying to determine the correct moral course of action.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Watch a film that considers a complex moral problem, such as the ethics of killing in A Time to Kill or the ethics of human experimentation in The Truman Show. Use this scenario as the basis for a discussion of the relevant moral issue and respond in essay or reflection on the morality of these behaviours.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: General activities

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Write a journal that reflects on the key ideas, terms and questions of ethics and moral philosophy.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Identify and discuss the moral questions raised by a viewpoint or an argument presented in a philosophical text.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Examine one or a variety of current issues in the print and/or visual media and identify, debate and evaluate the values and ethical dimension/s demonstrated by the viewpoints, arguments and responses.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Construct a web page that presents the viewpoints of several different philosophers in response to a question associated with an ethical problem. For example, how do different philosophers grapple with the relationship between reason, desire and action?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Use a moral dilemma in the form of a thought experiment to explore questions and issues associated with an ethical problem.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Write an essay comparing the viewpoints of two thinkers on the nature of good and evil.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Participate in a 'hypothetical' ethical dilemma (for example, The Experience Machine). Modify the roles or situations considered after each hypothetical and discuss why the responses offered might be similar or different.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Write a survey which seeks to examine commonly held moral views.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Individually, list the five most important elements for what constitutes the good life. With a partner, compare lists and create one list with the top six things agreed on. Then, as a class, create a list of the seven most important things that constitute a good life. Consider how ethical theories can illuminate the appropriate actions or motivations that could help us achieve these ends.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Write a reflection on the role of reason in moral decision-making. Extend this further by thinking about the role of character in moral decision-making. Stimulus material could include accounts of their actions by bravery medal winners and workplace whistle-blowers.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Design a webpage that includes a step-by-step process for ethical decision-making. What would be the benefits of such a page? What are the disadvantages? Can ethical decisions be simply charted like this? A good introduction to this issue is the debate over driverless cars; see 'Driverless cars will face ethical dilemmas'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Research and present a multi-media presentation on a contemporary ethical debate. Using a given set of pre-prepared cards, order an action on each card from morally praiseworthy to morally objectionable. Discuss how conclusions were reached about which acts are better/worse than others, including identifying the assumptions made.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Akrasia, pleasure, the good and the bad

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Context:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Ancient Greek philosophers were particularly concerned with explaining a state of mind in which someone acts against their better judgement, especially due to a lack of self-discipline or control or a weakness of will.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Students write a dialogue in response to the contemporary moral debate and may also perform it as a role-play, demonstrating their understanding of the meaning of akrasia and the difficulties it may pose in trying to lead a moral life.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Activity:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Students read either Plato's Protagoras, 351a-358d or Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, Book VII 1-10, or both. Once students have fully comprehended these extracts, they consider the following question: 'Is akrasia evidence that knowledge of good and bad can be overruled by pleasure?'

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Provide students with one or more contemporary moral debate(s) that might involve consideration of akrasia. For example, that only people with involuntary medical conditions should have access to medical assistance.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Students write a dialogue in response to the contemporary moral debate and may also perform it as a role-play, demonstrating their understanding of the meaning of akrasia and the difficulties it may pose in trying to lead a moral life.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Good intentions, good actions or good character?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Context:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Within normative ethics, there are four broad positions often examined in relation to the agent and the action they perform, and morality. Some theories emphasise that morality is dependent on the type of action performed, some that it is the consequences experienced, some that the intentions of the agent are paramount and, finally, some argue that it is the character of the agent performing the action which is the most important moral dimension of a situation.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Ask the class to consider a proposition related to one of these broad positions such as: 'What really matters is not what people do but rather what their intentions are.'

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Students construct a response in a variety of forms such as an essay, a classroom presentation or an online video.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Their response could include the following:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Their contention about whether they agree with this proposition or not

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: The reasons they have to support their position

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Examples or scenarios to support their point of view

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Counter-examples which might be used to demonstrate a flaw in their argument and their response to these.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Extension:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Ask students to then consider the following proposition: 'What really matters is not what people's intentions are but who they are.' Or 'What really matters is not who people are but what they do.' Students can respond to each intention in turn, or the class can be divided to consider one statement which is then reported back to the class. A proposition from another broad school of thought can then be selected and the process repeated. As students become more familiar with the schools of thought, they can bring this learning into their responses.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Journal reflection on values

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Students keep a personal journal or blog throughout the Area of Study for the purpose of reflecting on learning, skill development and, in particular, for reflecting critically on their own viewpoints and arguments relating to ethics and moral philosophy.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: For example, to assist students in beginning their journal, ask them to consider and answer the following questions to help them identify what they value:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Is there something that is important to you? What is it?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Do you know why this is important to you? If so, list the reasons and/or feelings you have to support your values.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Have you ever done anything that indicates that this is important to you?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Is this something you would stand by even if others strongly disagreed?.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Does this fit in with your vision of who you are? Why?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Have you ever encountered a situation where your own values conflict with each other? How did you resolve it?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Survey on morality and moral issues

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: As a class, devise several questions about current moral issues or classic thought experiments (e.g. Trolley Problems). Convert these into a survey (include ethical protocols such as seeking permission, written statements declaring what will be done with the data should be followed) and distribute. The questions for the survey could be broad such as in the example below. (Alternatively, one specific question be elaborated on further.)

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Can you teach morality? If so, how?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Is morality a type of knowledge?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Do you think that the media desensitises people to violence and that this causes more casual violence?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Do you think there are absolute moral wrongs and absolute rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Do you think religion influences people's moral values? To what extent?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Which has the most influence on your morals? Parents, religious education, school education, environmental or life factors or other? (Please define your response.)

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Once the results are in, collate the responses and discuss any apparent trends or widely held beliefs. Teachers should also encourage students to be critical of the method used to gain these responses, and think about whether those surveyed were willing to discuss these issues in a survey, or if it sets up false dichotomies. Students can also consider whether there are moral implications of such surveys - in what sense, if any, do surveys such as this, matter?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Extension:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ExampleText: Students examine Plato's arguments on the nature of morality and whether virtue can be taught in Meno Section 86-96.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Outcome 1:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Analyse selected problems in value theory and evaluate viewpoints and arguments in response to these problems, and discuss philosophical issues in the context of relevant contemporary debates.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: On rights and justice

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Use examples of speeches to stimulate consideration of the use of moral justifications for political positions and the significance of this.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine a moral dilemma and then discuss the relationship between morality and the law.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: As a class activity, draw a large tree trunk on a piece of butchers paper. On the tree, draw (in the form of leaves, fruit, flowers, branches) those rights that the class believes are essential for a human to flourish. Draw in roots and label with the fundamentals necessary for a human to grow. Participants should explain their additions to the drawing. This works particularly well with The Need for Roots by Simone Weil.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Draw a concept map that defines and links the following concepts: rights, responsibilities, obligations, duties, law, morality, etc.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Make a list of common rights. Discuss what makes these rights, rights, and reasons why these rights are valued. Consider who is entitled to such rights and who might not be and for what reasons. Discuss whether some of these rights are inalienable. Make a list of things not currently considered rights that you feel should be considered as such. Justify your thinking. Conclude by developing a shared definition of what a right is.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Construct a human figure on a chart. On the left side, list the various rights that a human being ought to be entitled to. On the right side, list the needs that are required for humans to achieve those rights. Discuss what might support and/or constrain the achievement of those rights. List below the figure the obligations of others and who bears these obligations. Consider whether obligations come prior to rights or whether rights come first.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Contrast the arguments within will theory to interest theory as to what the function of a right is.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Make a list of 'natural rights' and compare this to a list of 'legal rights'. Discuss which seems more important or significant or fundamental and why.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Define positive and negative rights and develop novel examples of each. Create scenarios where people interact with both kinds of rights.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Read the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948) and list the various rights entailed there. Consider what a revised version of that document could look like today and debate as a class the relative merits of different suggested additions and subtractions from the original document.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Write a written reflection on the UN Declaration of Human Rights. Consider the following: What are the aspirations of this document? Has it been effective? What might it take to be more effective?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Acquire your school's policy documents regarding rights for students. Analyse this to determine which theoretical positions underpin it.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Acquire your school's policy documents regarding rights for students. Analyse this to determine which theoretical positions underpin it.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research situations where someone might lose their rights, such as losing the right to vote when incarcerated for certain serious crimes. Consider the impact such right removal has on society and individuals and debate the virtue of such right removal.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Select a common right and analyse the constraints that exist in relation to it. For example, the common right of freedom of speech is curtailed by hate speech legislation. Evaluate the validity of constraints on rights and discuss whether there are any rights that should not have constraints and why.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research a historical civil rights case and examine the arguments made in that instance to justify the creation of new rights. Also consider the impact this creation had on existing rights and groups. Discuss when such impacts are and are not justified.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Create thought experiments where one right is challenged by another right to discuss which rights deserve primacy and why.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Brainstorm the responsibilities often associated with being a citizen of a society and discuss under what circumstances citizens can ignore these responsibilities and under what circumstances they cannot, as a basis of discussion of social contract theory.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Discuss the difference between freedoms and entitlements and their relative uses and values in a society. Research a common entitlement such as Medicare or public education, and compare this to a freedom such as association or worship to see the difference between liberty and claim rights.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Read an extract from Peter Singer's Animal Liberation and discuss the claims and merits of animal rights. Evaluate whether animal rights ought to be considered equal to human rights or less so and how such a claim can be justified.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Use a line debate to compare responses to moral positions such as 'Animals should have the same rights as humans'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research contemporary case studies from the media and consider arguments for and against the legal and moral points of view. For example, consider the legality of live animal export and the moral position for and against this practice, or the legality and moral standing of codes of practice, such as for the media.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research complex moral cases, such as female genital mutilation, on cultural grounds, and consider whether rights are connected to culture or supersede them. Discuss what obligations we must have to intervene in other people's lives in the event their actions contradict our own stated rights and responsibilities.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research common definitions of justice, such as conservative, ideal, corrective, distributive, procedural, substantive, comparative and non-comparative. Contrast this with famous definitions of justice, such as those found in Plato's Republic, and create posters on each form of justice, weighing up the pros and cons.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: In pairs or small groups, use the internet to research and develop an overview of a primary text such as Mary Wollstonecraft's A Vindication of the Rights of Woman (1792). Explore such elements as the biography of Wollstonecraft and the historical context of the book, the key issues raised and the critical reception of the book at the time and its relevance now.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: On liberty and anarchy

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Make a list of common choices people make, such as 'buying a book', 'getting a job', 'going to the public park', etc. Group these choices as a class in so far as they represent freedoms, or not.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Engage in a debate on questions of freedom and equality; for example 'Is it more important that each individual have absolute freedom to accumulate and spend wealth or that all basic goods be distributed equally among all people?'

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Take the 'Political Compass Test' and discuss the challenges that arise from people holding different positions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research historical events where individual freedoms were restricted by the state and consider the justifications used for these restrictions. Discuss these justifications and consider whether those states made reasonable or unreasonable choices.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Write an analysis of the role of the state when enforcing moral norms. The analysis should explore punishment and the courts, prisons and rehabilitation and the role of legislation.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Read an extract from Isiah Berlin's Two Concepts of Liberty to examine the difference between positive and negative liberty. Develop examples that reveal each and discuss their relative merits and criticisms.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Read an extract from Thomas Hobbes's Leviathan on the state of nature and contrast this account with John Locke's Two Treatises of Government and Jean-Jaques Rousseau's Of The Social Contract to consider different accounts of society and the function and role of the state.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Develop a slide presentation that outlines the viewpoints and arguments around the question of freedom of the individual in society and the role of the state. Specifically, explore whether there is a 'contract' between an individual and the society of which you are a part, where each has obligations and responsibilities toward the other. Refer to philosophers such as Locke, Hobbes, Rawls and Nozick.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Define different forms of government - democracy, autocracy, oligarchy, fascism, communism etc. Debate their relative merits and consider under what circumstances each might be the ideal. Reflect on democracy and consider whether this is the perfect system or whether improvements are needed. Make suggestions as to what these improvements could be and why.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Conduct a classroom forum or dialogue on a question associated with democracy. For example, 'What is democracy?'; 'Is democracy the best form of government?'; 'How sustainable is democracy and what are the essential elements of a democracy?'; 'How does democracy balance the needs of the individual with the needs of the community or society?' and 'Are the minority always bound by the will of the majority?' For extension, pose various problems to test values: 'Are we justified in going to war for democracy?' or 'Does a government have a mandate to rule if only 50%+1 of the populace voted for it?'

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Consider contemporary government restrictions such as censorship and bans on smoking and other drugs or other similar cases. Examine these cases in light of arguments found in John Stuart Mill's On Liberty and the work of Robert Nozick to test the practical and moral limitations of government intervention in the lives of citizens.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Imagine an ideal society where governments and citizens exist happily and in harmony. Describe the governmental systems, individual rights, freedoms, restrictions and responsibilities that might exist there. Compare this to our own society and develop a criticism of contemporary social life on this basis.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: On aesthetic value

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Draw a concept map that explores the relationship between the following concepts: art, craft, skills, technique, public consumption, usefulness, communication, adornment, aesthetic appeal, and so on.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Use a common search engine to search for 'beauty'. Examine the suggested images as a class and discuss what definition of beauty is being suggested. Debate as a class whether this is the class understanding of beauty or whether it is lacking some aspect of it. Reflect individually on what beauty means.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine a series of images debating in each case whether it is art or not and to what extent it presents beauty. Use this process to create a working definition of what constitutes art.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Read extracts from philosophers about beauty such as Plato's Symposium, Aristotle's Poetics, and David Hume's The Standards of Taste. Present their arguments in standard form and evaluate these to help build a personal definition of art and beauty.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Survey an art class in your school or the art faculty and ask them to define what art and beauty mean and the extent to which they are connected. Compare this with theoretical readings and in class discussion. Ask: 'Is art and beauty subjective or are experts better judges of what is and is not art and beauty?'. Reflect on these results as a class to develop definitions of beauty and art.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Consider different purposes of art - to please, to protest, to reflect, to challenge, to glorify, to propagandise, to extend, to innovate, to inform and so on. Find examples of art and artists who sought these purposes and consider the merits and problems associated with each interpretation of purpose.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research instances of censorship in art. Discuss whether censorship is ever justified and on what grounds.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine art through different theoretical lenses, such as Family Resemblance, Representation, Subjectivist, Aesthetic Emotion, Formalist, Expressionist, Institutional, Intentionality. Consider the ideas of each theory and determine which gives the most compelling account of art. Use these theories to examine various artworks to determine what they conclude and then critique these conclusions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Contrast examples of everyday art (a doodle in a workbook, a piece of graffiti, a drawing of a duck made by a child in school, etc.) with examples of famous artworks to discuss the position of art and whether a hierarchy exists defined by standards such as monetary value, skill of artist and so on. Use this as a basis for the relative merits of different artworks.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Visit the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art (ACCA). Explore and examine a range of question on the nature of art. Questions for discussion could be: What makes a piece of art an artwork? What is the purpose and value of art? Is there a distinction between high and low art?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Watch videos of people engaging in crafts such as woodworking, pottery or cookery. Discuss whether the practice of their craft constitutes a form of art and at what point. Contrast aesthetically pleasing work in these fields with more everyday work like that in common construction to make judgements around when a craft is art and when it may not be - if at all. Reflect on these ideas in a journal entry.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine a piece of art through a variety of lenses - a review from an expert, a child's opinion, an art student/teacher's opinion. Discuss the merits of each attitude to determine the value of expertise in aesthetic appreciation.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: On the interpretation of artworks

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Explore the various definitions of what makes an artefact a work or art. Some research may be required. Gather examples of works that accentuate the features of the various definitions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Write a reflection on whether an artist is a philosopher. For extension, construct an argument in standard form which characterises both occupations and then a further argument on whether they are the same, or not.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Take part in a Philosophy Trail at the National Gallery of Victoria (NGV). Explore and examine a range of questions on the role of beauty in art. Questions for discussion could be: What is beauty? Is beauty necessary for art? Can beauty be objectively defined?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Explore the relationship between various examples of contemporary art: painting, sculpture, dance, music, architecture. Discuss the features of each and attempt to come to a clear conclusion about the nature of a work of art.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Make the classroom into an art gallery. Each student contributes at least one work and discusses, in a brief presentation, why that work is considered art, what appealed in the work and why it was included in the class gallery.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine a current news dilemma surrounding art and explore the relevant aesthetic and/or moral issues involved. For example, controversies have arisen on provocative artistic representations of topics including: the human body, religious symbols, refugees, and so on.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Discuss the intentionalist fallacy as a class to determine whether the judgement of the worth of a piece of art is related to the intentions of the artist. Select a piece of art where the artist has provided a clear intention and compare this to a piece of art where the artist's intentions are unknown. Can we say that the work with known intentions is more or less valuable than other works? How can we justify this?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Read William K. Wimsatt and Monroe C. Beardsley's The Intentional Fallacy and lay out its arguments in standard form. Evaluate these.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Read the works of Michel Foucault and Jacques Derrida on the question of the role an author plays in their work. Discuss the significance of authorial intention and whether the author is an arbiter of truth on their work or whether the meaning of a work is disconnected from its author once completed.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Visit an art gallery and explore the question: Is art only ever found in an art gallery? On the way to the gallery, examine other visual representations such as advertising, tags and other graffiti, and consider the reasons why they should or should not be included in an art gallery.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Present a dialogue on the importance of art galleries in society. Explore a range of philosophical issues in the dialogue, including the role of art in society. Compare this with museums or libraries.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Interview fellow students on why they learn a musical instrument, participate in drama productions, or take art classes. What does this suggest about the value of art (or performance) in education or broader culture?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Explore the difference between art and propaganda. Useful examples can be found from political or historical sources, such as posters from Nazi Germany or paintings completed for the USSR.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Select a comedy sketch and watch it out of the context of the show it featured in - without providing explanation. For example, a short scene from a cartoon or an extended comedy show recorded for television. Afterwards, discuss the value and meaning of the scene. Then rewatch the scene with context provided and assess whether this context changes the meaning and value of the work. Use this observation as the basis for a reflective journal entry on context.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine a historical example of artistic censorship by the state and the rationale provided for this censorship. Discuss whether it is reasonably justified for the state to have behaved in that way or whether artistic freedom is a fundamental right of an artist.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText:
Explore the value of art by considering whether a forgery of a work of art provides the same viewer experience as the original. 
Write a response, such as an essay, on censorship of art. Draw on a philosopher's view on censorship of art, such as Plato.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine examples of sampling or covers in music. Discuss whether we should prioritise the original piece or whether the later versions have equal or greater artistic merit.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine an artist who engaged in printmaking (for example, MC Escher) and who printed multiple copies of their work using an original carving. Discuss where the art lies - in the original carving or in the subsequent prints and to what extent the number of available prints affects the value of the artwork.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Examine examples of the use of metaphor in music or print media. Discuss what is meant by a non-literal meaning and how this meaning is different from or like a literal meaning. Discuss whether non-literal meaning has truth value and what truth is being presented.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research past winners of a portrait competition such as the Archibald prize and consider the relationship between the subject of a work of art and the artist's interpretation of the subject. Look at how portraiture has been used historically as a way of presenting a person in their ideal light; for example, in royal portraits. Discuss whether the exchange of money between subject and artist damages the integrity of the artist.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Discuss whether the consumption of art makes people better, happier or more moral people. Use a stimulus for discussion, such as Picasso's anti-war work Guernica.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: General Activities

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Research thinkers and theories related to set topics. Use these findings for the basis of class debate.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Engage in creative writing to compare the ideas of different thinkers when pitted against one another by writing a dialogue.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Conduct surveys of peers to determine their opinions on complex questions of value. Use the results for further discussion and reflection.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Practise responding to stimulus material in the form of extracts from news articles and other media in response to set topics.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Engage in listing exercises to identify key concepts associated with questions of value. Develop class definitions through discussion and compare these to the positions of thinkers and theories from the course.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Using a moral dilemma to explore the relationship between law and morality

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: One well-known moral dilemma that explores the relationship between the law and morality is the Heinz dilemma. This scenario involves Heinz and his wife, who is near death. Her only hope is a new drug sold by a pharmaceutical company for $200,000. Heinz can only raise $50,000 and insurance will not cover the rest. He offers the $50,000 to the company, offering to pay the rest in instalments but the offer is refused. Heinz considers stealing the drug. Would that be wrong?

Subject: Philosophy

ExampleText: The United Nations' Universal Declaration of Human Rights

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: (adapted from: Human Rights Here and Now)

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Activity One:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Students read the 'UN Declaration of Human Rights' and note its scope and intention. They could also research the background to the drafting, including finding out more about the people on the committee, including the Australian William Hodgson.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Activity Two:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Provide students with a copy of the following extract from Eleanor Roosevelt on the UN Declaration of Human Rights (UNDHR):

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Where, after all, do universal rights begin? In small places, close to home - so close and so small that they cannot be seen on any maps of the world. Yet they are the world of the individual person; the neighbourhood he lives in; the school or college he attends; the factory, farm or office where he works. Such are the places where every man, woman, and child seeks equal justice, equal opportunity, equal dignity without discrimination. Unless these rights have meaning there, they have little meaning anywhere. Without concerned citizen action to uphold them close to home, we shall look in vain for progress in the larger world. (Eleanor Roosevelt, The Great Question, 1958)

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Lead a discussion on this extract, drawing out the relationship between a list of rights and practical action, for example along the following lines:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: What does Roosevelt mean by 'universal rights'?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: What is the relationship between an individual, the concept of rights and the wider world represented in this extract?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Evaluate Roosevelt's claim that the source of human rights are the 'small places'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Is it true that universal values or standards of behaviour are impossible?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Why did the U.N. chose the word 'universal' instead of the word 'international' when naming the UNDHR?

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: What does the final sentence of Roosevelt's quotation say about individual responsibility for human rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: What do you think Eleanor Roosevelt means by 'concerned citizen action to uphold' rights close to home?

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Philosophy Trails

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Students attend a Philosophy Trail at the National Gallery of Victoria (NGV). This excursion will allow students to explore the nature of art. Developed by the Victorian Association for Philosophy in Schools (VAPS), a Philosophy Trail is a program of philosophical discovery and reflection that invites students to tour and explore public spaces in Melbourne, and inquire into the values promoted within those public spaces. Students are led through a series of encounters at the venue that promote philosophical dialogue based on the Community of Inquiry methodology. Prior to the excursion, discuss the skills for participating in a Community of Inquiry. A model can be found At 'COI Model'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Before participating in the actual Philosophy Trail, develop responses, without prior research, to each of the following questions: What makes an artefact a work of art? What is the role of institutions such as the NGV in selecting and promoting art? Can beauty be objectively defined? Is beauty necessary in art?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: After completing the Philosophy Trail, students discuss the experience: What was interesting or challenging? What ideas changed or remain the same after the experience? Ask students to identify further philosophical questions raised by the Philosophy Trail. Then consider the questions raised prior to the excursion and discuss how the Philosophy Trail contributed answers. Later, students can further evaluate their initial reflections after completing their study of the Theme.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Philosophy Trails are also available by enquiry at the following public venues: State Library of Victoria, Melbourne Museum (Bunjilkaka exhibition and the Mind and Body Gallery) Barringa, Peninsula Gallery, Melbourne Zoo, Werribee Zoo and Healsville Sanctuary.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Using a hypothetical situation to explore the value of art

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: In either small groups or individually, students imagine they are a curator of a gallery. They have a large collection of art works which will be part of a prestigious and well publicised art show. Patrons will have to purchase expensive tickets to view the works. The curator becomes aware that some drawings are suspected of being forgeries by the prolific 20th century art forger, Eric Hebborn. To a typical art gallery patron, they are indistinguishable from the originals. Discuss the following in relation to whether the presence of forgeries matters for the experience of the viewer:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: What do you do and why?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Do you remove the pieces? If so, would the viewers nevertheless miss out on something?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Do you place signs on each suspected forged artwork warning the public they may be forgeries? If so, how might this affect the appreciation of the art by the viewer? If not, is this unethical? Why?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: If you were aware of research that showed that people's experience of originals and forgeries did not differ, would this make a difference to your actions?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Students provide reasoning to support their decisions and justify their actions.

ExampleText: Plato on censorship

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Context:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Plato, in the Republic, offers a consistent argument for the importance of censorship of artwork. His arguments can be found in Books 3 and 10. Teachers may like to examine the primary text itself and then continue with the discussion below. A website that offers a summary of Plato's main ideas as well as a standard form argument of Plato on censorship is 'Plato on censoring artists'. For a more contemporary discussion on Plato and censorship, see 'Plato's Pop Culture Problem, and Ours'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Activity:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Students write a dialogue with Plato arguing for or against Plato's position on censorship. Students could also write an essay, complete a speech, and so on. Students can draft their own questions in response to the Republic or use the following for discussion:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Does censorship improve or diminish educational opportunities? Most schools censor racist and hate pages using filters on the internet - is this 'good' censorship? Should racist images used in art be censored?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Is art educational?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: How should something like irony be responded to?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Does censorship harm or protect societies? Is there a difference between 'light' or 'heavy' censorship?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Do you think censorship violates freedom of speech? Should artists be treated differently or as ordinary citizens with regards to censorship of expression?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Is it up to the government or other agencies to censor things? Or should censorship be self-regulated, for example parents choosing what to censor for their children or an individual choosing not to watch particularly violent movies. What criteria could an artist use to self-regulate?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: What do you think censors would pay more attention to when monitoring content: print, songs, movies, or content on the internet? Do you think musical lyrics need censoring? Nudity in artworks? Violence in movies?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: What things should never be censored? What would the world be like if there was no censorship at all?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Discussion on beauty, art and morality

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ExampleText: Using a range of illustrative examples, discuss whether the beautiful has any moral significance. Then, introduce students to Pablo Picasso's Guernica and consider how the painting is regarded as art and arguments for the view that it does not need to be defined and evaluated by reference to beauty. Most people consider it to be great art; so, what are the characteristics that make it great art or do its distortions rely on a reference to beauty, after all? For extension, students may like to consider whether the stimulus for the painting (the bombing of a village in the Spanish Civil War) is appropriate subject matter for a work of art. Further, the artwork is one of the most important anti-war paintings in recent history. Students consider whether an artwork can have a moral message, whether it should have a moral message and, more generally, the role of art in moral education. They can find more information on the painting on the internet ('Guernica').

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: Identify a global issue that requires resolution. Analyse how questions of value, Epistemology and Metaphysics are relevant to this global issue. Evaluate whether it can be resolved using the techniques from Unit 1, Area of Study 1. Are there other forms of thinking that better resolve this issue? Discuss the value of philosophy based on this analysis and evaluation.

ExampleText: Reflective equilibrium: adjusting and modifying principles

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: Context:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: In 1971, John Rawls coined the term 'reflective equilibrium' to explain and elucidate 'a state of balance or coherence among a set of beliefs arrived at by a process of deliberative mutual adjustment among general principles and particular judgments'.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: As an example of reflective equilibrium, students consider how Western colonialists identified and resolved the logical inconsistencies in their prevailing moral codes between owning slaves, espousing democracy and universal human rights. Slavery and other 'isms' (e.g. sexism, racism and ageism) are useful for highlighting hypocritical attitudes from already established and contrasting moral principles. The method of reflective equilibrium requires us to seek coherence between our set of beliefs by making adjustments and modifications to our justifications from a principled position that we want to hold on to.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: Activity:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: Use the method of 'reflective equilibrium' to explore the aligning of experience and facts with a sense of justice. Students find an historical case where they illustrate and discuss how the method of equilibrium can be used to reconcile the nature of the case with a sense of justice.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: An alternative approach is to ask the class to imagine they were a parliament and that they had a conscience vote on a current issue; for example, organ donation, treatment of refugees or the definition of marriage. How could the method of equilibrium be used to assist in reaching a position? Students test this through role-playing a debate on a selected issue and reflecting on the process they used to come to a final position.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: Continuum or line debate

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: Students respond to statements about philosophical problems by placing themselves in a position on a physical 'line' in the classroom marked at either end with the words 'strongly agree' and 'strongly disagree'. These can be in relation to any of the areas studied in Units 1 and 2, such as epistemology and questions of value. For the latter, statements might include, for example: 'All children should go to school'; 'Families have no role in moral decisions'; 'Animals have no rights like human beings' and so on.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ExampleText: Students are asked to discuss and justify their position on the continuum. Their arguments and justifications, as well as any ambiguities that arise from these arguments, can be recorded and presented in a response to the exercise. In a bigger class, a teacher might divide the class into half. The first half can respond to the first set of questions while the second half records the responses and reasons. The groups should swap to ensure full engagement in the activity.
